content: any questions how to color change on the last stitch before the color change begin the last stitch as usual insert hook into the stitch yo and pull up a loop you should have 2 loops on the hook in the old color switch to the new color with the new color yo and pull through the 2 loops on your hook you should be left with 1 loop on your hook in the new color continue crocheting with the new color video tutorials color change on the rs https //youtube com/shorts/smx_755kxbe color change on the ws https //youtube com/shorts/jz49nw6jbna © 2024 earth hand & fiber page 3 pattern graph begin your project with a starting chain of 33 stitches in your chosen background color starting from the 2nd chain from your hook begin row 1 and single_crochet across you should have a total of 32 single_crochet by the end of the row continue by following the stitch charts below or by using the color block written instructions on pages 5-6 start here © 2024 earth hand & fiber page 4 color block begin your project with a starting chain of 33 stitches in your chosen background color starting from the 2nd white background color chain from your hook single_crochet across you should have a total of 32 single_crochet by the end of the row row 1 continue by black cat color following the color block instructions below starting from row 2 © 2024 earth hand & fiber page 5 border at the end of row 32 your working yarn should be on the upper right of your piece fasten_off and join your border yarn here crochet your border chain 1 single_crochet in the 1st st chain 1 skip single_crochet around your piece in each corner single_crochet chain 1 single_crochet © 2024 earth hand & fiber page 6 finishing steam block optional this is a good time to steam block your piece if you plan to do so steam blocking is a technique that uses hot steam to relax stitches and improve the shape of a crochet project i highly recommend blocking your piece before mounting to your dowel to ensure that your piece has a nice shape here are the general instructions for steam blocking 1 pin your piece to a foam blocking mat into the desired shape using blocking pins it s helpful to use a mat that has grid lines so that you can ensure that each side of your piece is consistent in length 2 using a fabric steamer hold the steam about 1-2 inches away from the piece and slowly wave back and forth steam the project for about 30- 60 seconds 3 let the piece cool for about 30 minutes or until dry then unpin from the blocking mat pictured is my mushroom bottle pattern in the video tutorial process of blocking this pattern is available on etsy ravelry & ko-fi https //youtube com/shorts/5qui5wm1rzs adding fringe start by cutting several strands of yarn approximately
